chunk_text: In the 20th century, English solidified its status as a global language, becoming the lingua franca of international communication, business, and diplomacy., During this period, English underwent a significant transformation in terms of vocabulary, pronunciation, and grammar., Middle English was spoken from the 11th to the 15th century and saw the introduction of many French words into the language., These Germanic tribes brought their language, which would eventually develop into Old English., The widespread use of English in technology, science, and entertainment further cemented its importance on the world stage., The British Empire's global influence contributed to the development of different English dialects and variations, such as American English, Australian English, and Indian English., Old English, also known as Anglo-Saxon, was spoken in England from the 5th to the 11th century., The 18th and 19th centuries saw the rise of the British Empire, which led to the spread of English to various parts of the world., The invention of the printing press by William Caxton in the late 15th century played a crucial role in the standardization of the English language., This period saw further changes to the English language, including the Great Vowel Shift, which altered the pronunciation of many words., Today, English is spoken by over 1.5 billion people worldwide and continues to evolve with the influence of technology and globalization., Caxton's printing press helped spread the use of English across England and contributed to the development of a more unified language., The history of the English language is a testament to its resilience and adaptability, reflecting the diverse cultures and peoples that have contributed to its development., ```English has a rich and fascinating history that spans over thousands of years, evolving into the widely spoken language we know today., The Early Modern English period began in the late 15th century and lasted until the mid-17th century., This led to the mixing of Old English and Old Norman, giving rise to Middle English., The works of William Shakespeare, considered one of the greatest writers in the English language, exemplify Early Modern English., The history of the English language can be traced back to the arrival of the Anglo-Saxons in Britain in the 5th century., In the late 11th century, the Norman Conquest of England brought about significant changes to the English language., In conclusion, the history of the English language is a story of evolution and transformation, shaped by various historical events and cultural influences., From its humble beginnings as Old English to its current status as a global language, English has come a long way and continues to be a vital means of communication in the modern world.```

entity.name: English
entity.description: A phase in the history of the English language that started in the late 15th century and ended in the mid-17th century.;;;A stage of the English language used from about 1500 to 1700, characterized by the Great Vowel Shift and the standardization of spelling.;;;The development and changes of the English language over time, influenced by various historical events and cultural interactions.;;;A West Germanic language that is the primary language of several countries and widely used as a lingua franca in international communication, business, and diplomacy.;;;The language used predominantly in England and many other countries around the world.;;;Another term for Old English, referring to the language spoken by the Anglo-Saxons in England from the 5th to the 11th century.;;;A West Germanic language that originated from Anglo-Frisian dialects brought to Britain in the mid-5th to 7th centuries by Anglo-Saxon settlers.;;;The West Germanic language that originated in England and is now widely used around the world.;;;A West Germanic language that originated from the Anglo-Frisian dialects brought to Britain in the mid 5th to 7th centuries AD by Anglo-Saxon settlers.;;;The form of English used from the late 11th century to the late 15th century, following Old English and preceding Early Modern English.;;;A West Germanic language that is the primary language of several countries, including the United Kingdom, the United States, and Australia.;;;A set of dialects of the English language used in the United States and some other countries.;;;A major variety of the English language, used primarily in Australia.;;;A West Germanic language that is the primary language of several countries and widely used as a lingua franca in many others.;;;The West Germanic language that originated from Anglo-Frisian dialects brought to Britain in the mid-5th to 7th centuries by Anglo-Saxon settlers.;;;An early form of the English language spoken from around 450 to 1150 AD.;;;An early form of the English language, spoken from around 450 to 1150 AD.;;;A West Germanic language that originated in England and is now widely used as a global lingua franca.;;;An early form of the English language spoken in England from the 5th to the 11th century, also known as Anglo-Saxon.;;;A West Germanic language that originated in England and is now widely spoken around the world.;;;The primary language spoken in England and many other countries around the world, with a rich history and global influence.;;;The earliest form of the English language, spoken in England from about the 5th to the mid-11th century.;;;A historical stage of the English language, spoken from the 11th to the 15th century.;;;The primary language used in England and many other countries, with a rich history of development and change.;;;A West Germanic language that originated from Anglo-Frisian dialects brought to Britain in the mid 5th to 7th centuries AD by Anglo-Saxon settlers.
